description: Hollow out a medium-sized pumpkin, removing seeds and fibers.
In a bowl, mix cooked rice with chopped dried fruits (apricots, prunes, raisins), nuts (almonds, walnuts), and honey.
Fill the pumpkin with the rice mixture and place a lid cut from the top.
Bake in a preheated oven at 375°F (190°C) until the pumpkin is tender and the filling is heated through.
Serve hot, cutting the pumpkin into wedges to expose the sweet, fragrant stuffing.
Cook chicken in water with salt until tender and the meat falls off the bones.
Remove the chicken, debone, and shred the meat.
Add washed khorasan wheat to the chicken broth and cook until the wheat is soft and begins to break down.
Add the shredded chicken back to the pot, continue to cook, stirring frequently, until the mixture becomes porridge-like.
Serve hot, topped with melted butter and a sprinkle of cinnamon.
Prepare the dough from flour, yeast, warm water, and salt, and let it rise until doubled in size.
Mix finely ground lamb or beef with finely diced tomatoes, bell peppers, onion, parsley, and spices.
Roll the dough into very thin circles, spread the meat mixture thinly on top.
Bake in a very hot oven for about 5 minutes until the edges are crisp and the topping is cooked.
Serve hot with a squeeze of lemon and fresh parsley.
Blanch broccoli florets in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain.
Marinate beef slices in a mixture of soy sauce, cornstarch, and a little oil.
Heat oil in a wok, add minced garlic, and stir-fry briefly until fragrant.
Add the marinated beef and stir-fry until it starts to brown.
Add broccoli and stir-fry for another 2 minutes.
Pour in a mixture of beef stock, oyster sauce, and a splash of soy sauce, and cook until the sauce thickens.
Serve hot.
Bring chicken broth to a simmer in a pot.
Season the broth with soy sauce, salt, and white pepper.
Slowly pour beaten eggs into the simmering broth, stirring gently to form ribbons.
Garnish with chopped green onions and a few drops of sesame oil.
Serve hot.
Marinate chicken pieces in soy sauce and cornstarch.
Heat oil in a wok and fry dried chilies until just beginning to blacken.
Add chicken to the wok and stir-fry until it turns white.
Add chopped bell peppers and scallions, stir-fry for a few minutes.
Pour in the sauce mixture of soy sauce, vinegar, sugar, and water, and cook until thickened.
Stir in roasted peanuts and serve.
Marinate chicken pieces in lemon juice and salt.
Cook onions in a dry pot until golden, then add berbere spice and oil, cooking into a paste.
Add garlic and ginger, then the marinated chicken, stirring to coat with the spice mixture.
Add enough water to cover, bring to a boil, then simmer until the chicken is tender.
Add hard-boiled eggs to the stew in the last 10 minutes.
Serve hot with injera.
Mix teff flour with water in a bowl until smooth, then cover and let ferment for 1-3 days.
After fermentation, stir the batter well and add salt.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat.
Pour a ladleful of batter into the pan and quickly swirl to spread in a thin layer.
Cover and cook for a few minutes until holes form on the surface and edges lift from the pan.
Remove injera and let cool on a clean cloth. Repeat with remaining batter.
Finely chop or grind fresh, lean beef.
Melt niter kibbeh in a pan and mix with mitmita.
Combine the spiced butter with the raw beef, mixing thoroughly.
Serve immediately with injera and optional ayib (fresh cottage cheese).
Brown the chicken pieces in a large dutch oven.
Remove chicken and sauté onions, mushrooms, and bacon in the same pot.
Deglaze the pot with red wine and return the chicken to the pot.
Add garlic, thyme, and bay leaf. Simmer until the chicken is tender.
Thicken the sauce with a butter-flour mixture before serving.
Heat cream with vanilla bean until just hot.
Whisk yolks with sugar until pale, then slowly add the hot cream.
Strain the mixture into ramekins.
Bake in a water bath until set but still trembling in the center.
Cool, then sprinkle sugar on top and torch until caramelized.
Caramelize the sliced onions in a large pot.
Add beef broth and bring to a simmer.
Season with thyme and bay leaves.
Toast baguette slices topped with grated cheese under a broiler until melted and golden.
Serve the soup hot with the toasted baguette.
Bake chocolate sponge cakes and let them cool.
Cut the cakes into layers and sprinkle each with cherry schnapps.
Whip cream with sugar and vanilla until stiff peaks form.
Assemble the cake by alternating layers of cake with whipped cream and cherries.
Decorate the top with whipped cream, chocolate shavings, and whole cherries.
Chill before serving.
Prepare the dough from flour, yeast, water, salt, and a bit of sugar.
Let the dough rise until doubled.
Divide the dough and roll each piece into a long rope, then twist into the traditional pretzel shape.
Dip each pretzel in a baking soda bath before baking to develop a golden and shiny crust.
Bake until golden brown and sprinkle with coarse salt while still warm.
Marinate the beef roast in a mixture of red wine, vinegar, onions, carrots, and spices for 2-3 days.
Remove the beef from the marinade, pat dry, and brown in hot oil in a heavy pot.
Strain the marinade and add it to the pot with the beef.
Add crushed ginger snaps to thicken and sweeten the sauce.
Simmer the roast slowly until it is tender.
Slice and serve the roast with the sauce poured over it.
Preheat oven and grease the baking dish.
Layer the filo dough with melted butter and chopped nuts.
Cut into diamond shapes before baking.
Bake until golden and crisp.
Pour cooled syrup over the hot baklava immediately after baking.
Chop the cucumbers, tomatoes, and red onion.
Combine vegetables in a large bowl.
Top with Kalamata olives and crumbled feta cheese.
Drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle oregano.
Slice and salt eggplants, then fry until golden.
Cook ground meat with onions, garlic, and tomatoes.
Layer eggplant and meat mixture in a baking dish.
Prepare béchamel sauce and spread over the top.
Bake until the surface is golden and bubbly.
Marinate chicken in yogurt, garlic, ginger, and spices for at least 2 hours.
Cook rice until it's 70% done, then drain.
Fry onions until golden, then set aside.
Layer the marinated chicken and partially cooked rice in a pot.
Add saffron infused in warm milk for color.
Cover and cook on low heat until the rice is fully cooked and the chicken is tender.
Garnish with fried onions, nuts, and fresh cilantro.
Peel and chop fresh mangoes.
Blend mangoes with yogurt, milk, sugar, and cardamom until smooth.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least one hour.
Serve cold garnished with a sprinkle of cardamom powder or mint leaves.
Blanch spinach in hot water, then cool and blend into a fine paste.
Fry paneer cubes until golden, set aside.
In the same pan, sauté onions, tomatoes, garlic, and ginger until soft.
Add the spinach paste, spices, and a little water to the pan.
Simmer for 10 minutes, then add fried paneer.
Cook for another 5 minutes, then serve hot with naan or rice.
Season veal shanks with salt and pepper and dredge in flour.
Brown the veal shanks in a heavy pot with some olive oil.
Remove shanks and sauté onions, carrots, and celery until softened.
Deglaze the pot with white wine, then return the shanks to the pot.
Add broth until the shanks are nearly covered, bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer.
Cover and cook slowly until the meat is tender, about 2 hours.
Serve with gremolata on top.
Cook spaghetti in salted boiling water until al dente.
Render pancetta in a pan until crispy.
Whisk eggs and Parmesan cheese together in a bowl.
Drain pasta and mix into the pan with pancetta, off the heat.
Quickly add egg and cheese mixture, stirring vigorously to create a creamy sauce.
Season with freshly cracked black pepper and serve immediately.
Mix egg yolks and sugar until pale and fluffy.
Fold in mascarpone cheese gently.
Dip ladyfingers in coffee mixed with a splash of coffee liqueur.
Layer the ladyfingers in a dish, spread over a layer of mascarpone mixture.
Repeat layering and refrigerate for at least 4 hours.
Dust with cocoa powder before serving.
Whisk together milk, cream, sugar, and matcha powder until the sugar dissolves.
Chill the mixture in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours.
Process in an ice cream maker according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Freeze the churned ice cream until firm, about 2-3 hours.
Prepare the broth by simmering chicken or pork bones with onions, garlic, and ginger.
Strain the broth and season with soy sauce, miso, or salt.
Cook ramen noodles separately until just tender.
In bowls, arrange cooked noodles, then pour hot broth over them.
Top with slices of pork belly, soft-boiled eggs, green onions, and bamboo shoots.
Cook sushi rice and season with sushi vinegar.
Spread the cooled rice on a sheet of nori laid out on a bamboo mat.
Place fillings like cucumber, avocado, and fish along the center of the rice.
Roll the nori tightly using the bamboo mat, pressing firmly.
Slice the roll into 6-8 pieces with a sharp knife.
Boil large cuts of meat until tender, then remove the meat and reserve the broth.
Hand-make pasta dough, roll it out thinly, and cut into squares.
Cook the pasta squares in the remaining broth until tender.
Slice the boiled meat into bite-sized pieces.
Layer the cooked pasta on a large serving platter, top with meat pieces, then ladle hot broth over the top.
Garnish with chopped parsley and serve.
Prepare the intestines by thoroughly cleaning and then soaking in cold water.
Cut the horse meat and fat into strips, season with salt, pepper, and minced garlic.
Stuff the seasoned meat and fat tightly into the intestines.
Tie off the ends of the sausage and boil in water for an hour, or smoke for several hours until cooked through.
Serve sliced with traditional sides of bread and onions.
Drain the whey from sour milk or yogurt completely.
Mix the curd with salt and press any remaining liquid out.
Form the curd into small balls and cover them in cloth.
Leave the balls to dry in a cool, ventilated area until hard.
Store in a dry place until ready to consume.
Marinate the meat in a mixture of lemon juice, garlic, ginger, and salt for at least 1 hour.
Prepare a charcoal grill or preheat a gas grill.
Grill the meat over medium heat, turning regularly, until well browned and cooked to desired doneness.
Rest the meat for 10 minutes before slicing.
Serve with kachumbari (a fresh tomato and onion salad) and Ugali.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add minced garlic and continue to sauté for about 1 minute.
Add the chopped collard greens, stirring to combine with the onions and garlic.
Season with salt, pepper, and a pinch of cayenne for heat.
Cover and simmer over low heat until the greens are tender, adding a little water if necessary.
Serve hot with Ugali or as a side dish to any meal.
Bring water to a boil in a large pot.
Slowly pour the cornmeal into the boiling water, stirring continuously with a wooden spoon.
Continue to cook and stir until the mixture thickens and pulls away from the sides of the pot.
Turn out the Ugali onto a plate and mold into a round shape.
Serve hot with a stew or vegetables.
Cook the rice according to package instructions.
Prepare and sauté each vegetable separately in a pan with a small amount of oil.
Marinate beef slices in soy sauce, garlic, and sesame oil, then fry until cooked.
Fry an egg, keeping the yolk runny.
Assemble the dish by placing rice in a bowl, arranging the vegetables and beef on top, and placing the fried egg in the center.
Serve with a dollop of gochujang on the side.
Prepare the dough with flour, sugar, milk, and yeast. Let it rise until doubled in size.
Mix brown sugar, chopped nuts, and cinnamon for the filling.
Divide the dough into balls, flatten them, and place a spoonful of filling in the center.
Seal the dough around the filling and flatten into a pancake shape.
Fry each pancake in a lightly oiled pan until golden brown on both sides.
Serve hot, allowing the syrupy filling to ooze out when bitten.
In a pot, sauté pork belly until browned, then add chopped kimchi and cook until soft.
Add water or stock and bring to a boil.
Season with gochujang, gochugaru (Korean chili powder), and soy sauce.
Add sliced tofu and simmer until all ingredients are well-cooked.
Garnish with sliced green onions and serve hot with a bowl of rice.
Roast poblano peppers, peel off the skin, and remove seeds.
Prepare the picadillo by cooking ground meat with tomatoes, apples, pears, and peaches.
Stuff the roasted chiles with the picadillo.
Prepare a sauce by blending walnuts with milk, sugar, and sherry until smooth.
Cover the stuffed chiles with the walnut cream sauce.
Garnish with pomegranate seeds and parsley before serving.
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).
Melt sugar in a pan until golden and pour into a round baking dish, swirling to coat the bottom.
Blend eggs, condensed milk, evaporated milk, and vanilla extract until smooth.
Pour the custard mixture over the caramelized sugar.
Place the dish in a larger baking pan and fill the pan with hot water halfway up the sides of the dish.
Bake in a water bath until set, about 45 minutes.
Cool and refrigerate before serving. Invert onto a plate to serve.
Marinate thinly sliced pork in a blend of chilies, achiote paste, garlic, and pineapple juice overnight.
Cook the pork on a vertical spit or in a very hot skillet until charred and tender.
Chop the cooked pork into small pieces.
Warm small corn tortillas and fill with pork.
Top with diced pineapple, chopped onions, and fresh cilantro.
Serve with a squeeze of lime and salsa.
Preheat the oven and grease the baking dish.
Layer the filo dough in the dish, brushing each sheet with melted butter and sprinkling chopped nuts between some of the layers.
Cut the layered pastry into diamond or square shapes before baking.
Bake until golden and crisp.
Immediately after baking, pour the prepared syrup evenly over the hot baklava.
Let cool to absorb the syrup before serving.
Grill seasoned lamb strips until well cooked.
Toast pita bread lightly and cut into small pieces.
Place the bread in a dish and cover with grilled lamb.
Heat tomato sauce and pour over the meat.
Melt butter and drizzle over the dish.
Serve with a side of fresh yogurt.
Prepare the dough from flour, water, yeast, and salt. Let it rise for an hour.
Mix minced meat with finely chopped bell peppers, tomatoes, onions, parsley, and spices.
Roll out the dough into thin circles and spread the meat mixture thinly on top.
Bake in a very hot oven until the edges are crisp and browned, about 5 minutes.
Serve hot, rolled up with a squeeze of lemon and optional garnishes like lettuce and sliced tomatoes.
Prepare the dough by mixing flour, water, salt, and a bit of oil into a smooth, elastic dough. Let it rest.
For the filling, combine finely chopped spinach, green onions, dill, parsley, and optional cheese.
Divide the dough into small balls, roll each out thinly, place a spoonful of filling in the center, then fold and seal the edges.
Fry each pie in hot oil until golden brown on both sides.
Drain on paper towels and serve warm.
Heat oil in a large pot and brown the lamb pieces until golden.
Add chopped onions and grated carrots to the pot and sauté until softened.
Stir in rice, Turkmen saffron, and enough boiling water to cover the ingredients.
Cook on low heat until the rice is fluffy and all the liquid is absorbed.
Serve hot, garnished with fresh herbs.
In a large pot, brown the lamb pieces to develop flavor.
Add water and bring to a boil, skimming off any foam that forms on the surface.
Add chopped potatoes, carrots, onions, and bell peppers to the pot.
Season with salt, pepper, and a bouquet garni of local herbs.
Simmer gently until the meat is tender and vegetables are cooked.
Serve hot, sprinkled with chopped herbs like dill and parsley.
Soak dried fruits in hot tea the night before baking to plump them up.
Mix flour, sugar, and spices in a bowl.
Add the soaked fruits with any remaining tea, followed by an egg, and mix to form a dough.
Pour the batter into a greased loaf pan.
Bake in a preheated oven at 350°F (175°C) for about 1.5 hours until risen and golden.
Cool in the pan, then turn out onto a wire rack.
Slice and serve with butter.
In a large pot, brown the lamb pieces, then remove and set aside.
In the same pot, sauté onions, carrots, and leeks until slightly softened.
Return the lamb to the pot, add potatoes, and cover with water or stock.
Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer, covering and cooking for at least 3 hours until the meat is tender and the vegetables are cooked.
Season with salt and pepper to taste, and add chopped parsley before serving.
Serve hot, with a side of crusty bread.
In a saucepan, melt butter and stir in the flour to make a roux.
Gradually add beer to the roux while continuously stirring to create a smooth sauce.
Add grated cheese to the saucepan, stirring until the cheese is melted.
Season the cheese sauce with mustard, Worcestershire sauce, and a pinch of salt and pepper.
Pour the hot cheese sauce over slices of toasted bread.
Grill the topped bread under a broiler until bubbly and golden brown.
Serve immediately.
Brown lamb pieces in a skillet with a little oil.
Place lamb in a baking dish and cover with rice and water.
Bake in the oven at 375°F for 30 minutes.
Whisk together yogurt, eggs, and flour; pour over the lamb and rice.
Return to oven and bake until the topping is golden and set.
Serve hot.
Prepare phyllo dough and layer half in a greased baking dish.
Mix chopped walnuts, sugar, and cinnamon; spread over the phyllo.
Top with the remaining phyllo, brushing each layer with melted butter.
Cut into diamonds and bake at 350°F until golden and crisp.
Pour syrup made from sugar, water, and lemon juice over the hot pastry.
Allow to cool before serving.
Sauté chopped onions and bell peppers in olive oil until soft.
Add chopped tomatoes and simmer until the mixture thickens.
Stir in crumbled cottage cheese and season with salt and pepper.
Cook until everything is heated through.
Serve warm with crusty bread.
Prepare rice according to package instructions.
Mix cooked rice with chopped herbs, garlic, and precooked shrimp.
Cut tops off bell peppers and remove seeds.
Stuff peppers with rice mixture, place in a baking dish.
Bake at 375°F until peppers are soft and filling is hot.
Serve with lemon wedges.
Preheat oven to 350°F.
Sauté spinach until wilted, then mix with crumbled feta cheese and eggs.
Layer phyllo sheets in a greased baking pan, brushing each with oil.
Spread spinach mixture over phyllo, then cover with more phyllo sheets.
Bake until golden brown.
Cut into squares and serve.
Soak beans overnight, then drain and rinse.
Sauté onions and garlic in a pot until translucent.
Add beans, water, and chopped tomatoes. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer.
Cook covered on low heat for 2 hours until beans are tender.
Season with salt, pepper, and a pinch of chili powder.
Serve hot with bread.
Preheat oven to 350°F.
Prepare cake batter with eggs, sugar, and ground walnuts.
Pour into a greased pan and bake until a toothpick comes out clean.
Simultaneously, prepare syrup with sugar, water, and lemon juice.
Pour hot syrup over the hot cake after removing from oven.
Let absorb and cool before serving.
Cook rice until tender, then mix with beaten eggs, chopped mint, and salt.
Heat oil in a deep skillet.
Form rice mixture into small balls and fry until golden and crispy.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot.
Slice zucchini, bell peppers, eggplants, and tomatoes into even pieces.
Marinate with olive oil, garlic, and herbs.
Grill on high heat until vegetables are tender and have grill marks.
Serve hot or at room temperature, garnished with fresh basil.
Clean mussels and discard any that are open and do not close when tapped.
Heat olive oil in a large skillet, add minced garlic, and sauté until fragrant.
Add mussels and cover with white wine, simmer until mussels open.
Sprinkle with chopped parsley and serve hot.
Serve with pasta or fresh bread.
Form ground beef into patties and season with salt and pepper.
Grill patties on medium-high heat until desired doneness.
Place a slice of cheese on each patty in the last minute of cooking to melt.
Toast hamburger buns on the grill.
Assemble the burgers by placing lettuce, tomato, patty with cheese, onions, and pickles on the bun.
Serve with ketchup, mustard, or mayonnaise.
Prepare the pie crust and line a pie dish with one layer of crust.
Mix sliced apples with sugar, cinnamon, and flour.
Fill the pie crust with the apple mixture.
Cover with the second layer of crust, seal edges, and cut small slits in the top.
Bake at 375°F until the crust is golden and the filling is bubbly.
Serve warm with vanilla ice cream.
Combine flour, salt, pepper, paprika, and garlic powder in a bowl.
Dip chicken pieces in beaten eggs, then dredge in flour mixture.
Heat oil in a deep fryer or large skillet to 350°F.
Fry chicken until crispy and cooked through, about 10 minutes per side.
Drain on paper towels and serve.
Cook macaroni according to package instructions; drain.
In a saucepan, melt butter and stir in flour to make a roux.
Gradually add milk to the roux, stirring constantly until thickened.
Remove from heat and mix in grated cheese until melted.
Combine cheese sauce with macaroni, transfer to a baking dish, and bake at 375°F for 20 minutes.
Optionally, top with breadcrumbs and bake until golden.
Rub ribs with a mixture of paprika, garlic powder, salt, and sugar.
Wrap ribs in foil and bake at 275°F for 3 hours until tender.
Remove ribs from foil, brush with barbecue sauce, and grill for 10 minutes on each side.
Serve with extra barbecue sauce.
Mix flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt in a bowl.
In another bowl, whisk together milk, egg, and melted butter.
Combine the wet and dry ingredients until just mixed; some lumps are okay.
Heat a griddle or skillet over medium heat and pour batter to form pancakes.
Cook until bubbles form on the surface, then flip and cook until golden.
Serve with butter and maple syrup.
Cream together butter and sugars until fluffy.
Beat in eggs and vanilla extract.
Mix in flour, baking soda, and salt.
Stir in chocolate chips.
Drop spoonfuls of dough onto a baking sheet and bake at 350°F for 10 minutes or until golden.
Cool on a wire rack before serving.
Cook bacon until crispy.
Toast slices of bread.
Spread mayonnaise on one side of each slice of bread.
Layer crispy bacon, sliced tomatoes, and lettuce leaves on one slice, then top with another slice of bread.
Cut in half and serve.
Cook chopped bacon until crisp; set aside.
In the same pot, sauté onions and celery until soft.
Add potatoes, clams with juice, water, and seasonings; simmer until potatoes are tender.
Stir in cream and heat through without boiling.
Serve garnished with crispy bacon and oyster crackers.
Melt butter and chocolate together.
Stir in sugar, eggs, and vanilla extract.
Mix in flour, cocoa powder, and salt.
Fold in additional chocolate chunks.
Pour batter into a greased baking pan and bake at 350°F for 25 minutes.
Cool in pan before cutting into squares and serving.
Chop tomatoes, cucumbers, and onions into bite-sized pieces.
Combine in a bowl and season with salt and olive oil.
Top with grated sirene cheese and a sprinkle of parsley before serving.
Brown the meat in a pot with some oil.
Add chopped onions, peppers, and mushrooms to the pot and sauté until soft.
Stir in paprika, a splash of white wine, and tomato paste. Cover and simmer for an hour.
Season with salt, pepper, and fresh herbs before serving.
Mix beaten eggs with crumbled sirene cheese and yogurt.
Layer sheets of phyllo dough in a greased baking dish, brushing each with melted butter.
Spread the egg and cheese mixture between layers of phyllo.
Bake at 375°F until golden brown and puffed.
Cut into squares and serve hot.
Mix flour, yeast, and yogurt to form a soft dough. Let it rise until doubled.
Heat oil in a deep fryer.
Roll out small pieces of dough and fry until golden brown on both sides.
Drain on paper towels and sprinkle with powdered sugar, or serve with honey or jam.
Layer thinly sliced potatoes and seasoned minced meat in a baking dish.
Mix eggs with yogurt and pour over the layers.
Bake at 350°F until the top is golden and the potatoes are tender.
Allow to set before serving.
Combine yogurt with water to a soup-like consistency.
Add finely chopped cucumbers, crushed garlic, chopped dill, and crushed walnuts.
Season with salt and olive oil.
Chill in the fridge for at least an hour before serving.
Layer kadaif dough in a tray, interspersing with mixed nuts.
Bake until golden brown.
Pour a hot syrup made of sugar, water, and lemon juice over the baked kadaif.
Let it cool and absorb the syrup before serving.
Toast bread slices lightly.
Spread a thick layer of grated Bulgarian cheese on each slice.
Broil in the oven until the cheese is bubbly and golden.
Optionally top with a fried egg and serve immediately.
Prepare walnut sponge layers by beating egg whites with sugar and folding in ground walnuts and flour.
Bake each layer separately until set.
Prepare chocolate ganache with heavy cream and dark chocolate.
Assemble the cake by layering sponge and ganache, finishing with a ganache topping.
Chill in the fridge to set before serving.
Prepare cabbage leaves by boiling until tender.
Mix minced meat with rice, onions, and spices.
Place a spoonful of the filling on each leaf and roll tightly.
Arrange the rolls in a pot, cover with tomato sauce and water.
Simmer on low heat until the meat and rice are fully cooked.
Serve hot, garnished with fresh herbs.
Slice beef into thin strips.
Season beef with salt and pepper.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat and sauté onions until translucent.
Add beef to the pan and brown.
Reduce heat and add mustard and beef broth. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Stir in sour cream and cook for another 5 minutes without boiling.
Serve hot over noodles or rice.
Mix honey, sugar, and eggs in a bowl.
Add baking soda and melt mixture over steam until it increases in volume.
Mix flour into the warm honey mixture to form dough.
Divide the dough into 8 parts, roll out each and bake for 5 minutes at 350°F.
Whisk sour cream with sugar and vanilla.
Spread cream between each cooled cake layer.
Coat the outside with leftover cream and crumble a baked dough layer on top.
Chill in fridge overnight before serving.
Peel and chop all vegetables.
Sauté onions and carrots in a pot.
Add beets and continue to sauté for a few minutes.
Add water, cabbage, and potatoes and bring to a boil.
Simmer until all vegetables are tender.
Add vinegar, sugar, and salt to taste.
Serve with sour cream and fresh dill.
Mix flour, eggs, water, and salt to form a dough.
Roll dough thin and cut into circles.
Place a small amount of meat filling in the center of each circle.
Fold dough over and seal edges to form a dumpling.
Boil dumplings in salted water until they float to the surface.
Serve hot with melted butter or sour cream.
Mix tvorog, eggs, flour, sugar, and vanilla.
Form small patties from the mixture.
Fry patties in a hot, oiled pan until golden brown on both sides.
Serve hot with sour cream or jam.
Rinse buckwheat groats under cold water.
Bring water to a boil and add groats.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer until groats are tender and water is absorbed.
Serve hot with milk or as a side dish to meat.
Mix honey, sugar, and spices in a bowl.
Add eggs and melted butter, then blend in flour to form a stiff dough.
Roll out dough and cut into shapes.
Bake at 350°F for 15-20 minutes.
Mix powdered sugar with lemon juice to make icing.
Glaze cookies after they have cooled.
Puree apples and mix with sugar.
Heat mixture until sugar dissolves.
Whip egg whites to stiff peaks.
Gradually combine hot fruit mixture with egg whites.
Pipe onto parchment paper into desired shapes.
Let dry at room temperature for 12 hours.
Boil potatoes, carrots, and eggs until cooked.
Dice all cooked ingredients and pickles.
Combine in a bowl with peas and diced chicken.
Mix thoroughly with mayonnaise.
Chill before serving.
Sauté onions and carrots in a pot.
Add meat (beef or pork) and sauté until browned.
Add water and bring to a boil.
Add chopped cabbage and potatoes, simmer until all ingredients are tender.
Season with salt, pepper, and herbs before serving.
Serve with a dollop of sour cream.
